If The grave Elizabethan house, , within, as we

with its surroundings, it is because the rela its the connection

If we could see it as it was when in being
as the airman sees it as it was when in being we
should see the the farm, the cottage, roads as an
airman sees the foundations of old towns
still existing marked on the fields, we should see
the great tracks leading from the farm & the cottage;
we should see the great house as an oasis in the
in the midst of wild country;

If we could see the great house as it was when

& barns. We should see it like a green oasis in

It it was [meaning?] If of the great house were to
[detect?] the enemy that it should the enemy, [man?]
that there should was be armour in the church: to
fight against hunger in winter there should be grain in the
barn. The common fight linked the great house to the

in so many between master & man that is
seen detail detailed so painfully & minutely in the
medieval account books, inventories, that is
so minutely & painfully revealed in the innumerable
in the letters: it makes the staple of

also the other connection – there was the
common belief: that bond between the

No one uses it now. But in the when came to

hovel. They believed In the spring they danced
round the maypole; in summer at midsummer the
bon fire was lit on the hill; at harvest time the
waggons were crowned: at Christmas the mummers & the
wassailers sung under the windows: Long They
rem believed Beneath the the tree Summer
Spring & summer & winter were gods. The sea was
a god, the earth a goddess. This ancient belief
lay beneath the Christian belief;
& there was still in being the old Pagan
was still in being; the old Eight gods were
the Pagan Gods were still in the fields to be
worshipped alive to be [remembered?], to be worshipped.
And Even if the Christian faith had And

the Even if the service of the Pagan gods was

& even the names of the Pagan gods were

& to induce the rhymers & the mummers, the

That was the other bond between the great
house & the cottage. For though the great,
with their with their acga speaking
French as easily as English, with their Latin & greek
tags on their tongues, despised the
must despise the jargon of the peasant, they
shared the superstitions. An old woman in a
cott hovel was to the King himself even,
the [venal?] of an unclean spirit. A dun
chicken, she said, sucked on her chin. When the
were applied to her, she confessed
on all Hallows E'en last she with 200
witches had gone to sea, each one in a
[riddle?] a sieve drinking & making merry
till they came to the Kerk of
in where they landed & danced a
reel. When the died a witch was
[illeg.] in the corner of his room. She confessed
how she had thrown a cat into the sea &
raised a storm that had sunk the Kings ships.

The great house, then, when the nobles read
the aloud, was connected
with the village by these superstitions, needs, beliefs.

div.p:
There is an entry in diary, which
Henslowe in had jotted down in his diary the cost of
the lathe, the nails, the timber that he had
bought. For painting the theatre
and for the clothes worn by the play Hens–
that was the house that the playhouse
was being built on the Banks of the Thames.

But how far was the author playwright in 1570 separate
from the minstrel, the ballad singer?
The past seems to be that, when Spenser
Attached his name to the , the author of
left his work gu unsigned
This is a sign of the that there were two publics:
the reading, & the playgoing. There is a division
It marks a distinction between two kinds of
writer – two methods, too two attitudes of mind.
If there had been no minstrel, would English literature
had remained a read, a book literature?
No stage, no common art; but always one book to be
read, privately; –

It is but a childs world; it is a world
before the self consciousness had added any
mirror. There are men & women

angular, gigantic; freed from something impure; yet
old; sin tarnishedl corruptL in the middle of
the fresh, innocent landscape, remembering;–
par It To follow the Knights & ladies in this
strange pre-historic England is to lose our bearings (beags); to
shed many habits of thoughtl but we after all
this it is not an imprinted fabricated world; it is
behind us still, deep down; & savage, primitive, still
existing ending

But Of the writer, nothing is known.
He does not exist apart from his book. It is
like the anonymous voice speaking
anonymously; the voice of a very old yet still still
common world, where the story is already known to
the listener, where the listener the listener
the voice of an unknown man, who has been
travelling in strange parts, & comes to the
door, across the marsh, through the flood,
to remind the noble & the peasant of what
he has heard long ago.

In the great house & in the cottage this half articulate
anonymous voice murmured of old Gods, & Kings, & Knights
& Ladies. The well & the tree were still
haunted. the traveller tell
XVII that about noon, or about midnight, when the
moon is full & shining, they often see an assay of
hawkers with dogs & sound of horses, who, in
answer to the [enquiries?] say that they are
of the [homestead?] & fellowship of Arthur."
Along the roads from town to town, from one
great house to another came the [mummers?] & the
rhymers, the jugglers the bear leaders, the
speakers of ballads, the fo while for these
who could read it & hear it,
book told the story of .

Then, the instinct to enact, to impersonate
what they see heard came into being. Even the King &
Queen must have their minstrels to give shape
to this hidden instinct. The author was
[special?]: the for he displayed his body: after,
because, feeling himself an outcast, he used the
outsiders privilege (prvilge) to of irresponsible
mockery. Yet just as we isolate those who
say what we are too proud to admit, the
minstrel was tolerated. Even the churchmen,
aware that the other gods than his were
being worshipped, mus could not suppress the
actor. When he was no longer If they could,
they constrained the juggler & the dancer
to put off their leaves & their bells & to
robe themselves as the [pilgrimages?] in a miracle
play. But when the old pl story religious (relgios)
story was stale, they left played in the
[courtyard? churchyard?], & at last set up their pageant in the
market place.
